keyTakeaways: Deep work is increasingly rare and increasingly valuable
Shallow work—email, meetings, social media—crowds out meaningful work
Attention is a muscle that can be trained
Schedule deep work sessions and protect them ruthlessly
The ability to focus is becoming a competitive advantage
summary_short: Cal Newport argues that 'deep work'—focused, uninterrupted concentration—is rare and valuable. While everyone's drowning in email and social media, those who can do deep work will thrive. A manifesto for meaningful productivity.
summary_medium:
Why This Book Matters

Knowledge workers are increasingly unable to focus. Newport argues this is a crisis—deep work produces value, but our environment systematically prevents it.

Deep vs Shallow

Deep work: cognitively demanding tasks performed without distraction. Shallow work: logistical tasks done while distracted. Most 'work' is shallow.

The Rules

Work deeply (schedule blocks, create rituals). Embrace boredom (train focus by resisting distraction). Quit social media (or limit dramatically). Drain the shallows (minimize low-value tasks).
